summary: hepatitis a virus is a major cause of foodborne illness, due in large part to the contamination of shellfish by hepatitis A virus (HAV) the prototype of the Hepatovirus genus is composed of an icosahedral capsid that contains a positive sense single-stranded RNA genome. infection is associated with the consumption of virus-contaminated bivalves, including oysters, clams, cockles and mussels. low pH and divalent metal ions enhance the interaction between HAV and BS-C-1 cells due to changes in the viral capsid conformation [11]. the detection of HAV is not directly compatible with PCR, because the method requires an appropriate concentration of sample, removal of interfering substances and the ability to distinguish between infectious and non-infectious virus particles. gG, Lopez-Sabater et al. were able to capture HAV from shellfish extract and remove the interfering materials present. the method currently being used requires expensive antibodies from animal sources. the alternative method would be highly desirable to reduce the cost.
